name_of_ordered_mutable_list.name: What is a ordered (not sorted) mutable list called?

create_a_ordered_mutable_list.name: Create the list
create_a_ordered_mutable_list.comment: First line creates an empty array. Second line creates an array with 3 string values: 'apple', 'orange', and 'tomato'. Third line shows off that you can put different types in one array. The fourth line creates an array with 3 items, and executes the code in the block to figure out the value at that index. In this case, it always returns the string 'Repetitive', so you have an array of 3 strings: 'Repetetive'.

ordered_mutable_list_start_number.name: What number does it start at?

ordered_mutable_list_can_be_inserted_in_.name: Can you insert into the middle of it?

insert_into_middle_of_ordered_mutable_li.name: Insert element in middle
insert_into_middle_of_ordered_mutable_li.comment: The first line inserts the word 'fourth' at the 3 index or the fourth position in the array. The second line inserts the word 'middle' in the exact middle of the array. The third line sets the 2 index of the array to 'excuse me' and replaces 0 positions, resulting in 'excuse me' being added to the array in the third position, and the previous third position being moved to the fourth (and so on).

delete_ordered_mutable_list.name: Delete the list
delete_ordered_mutable_list.comment: Why delete the list? Line 1 reassigns the variable to nothing. Line 2 empties the array.

name_of_sorted_mutable_list.name: What is a sorted mutable list called?

sorted_mutable_list_start_number.name: What number does it start at?

sorted_mutable_list_can_be_inserted_in_m.name: Can you insert into the middle of it?

name_of_unordered_mutable_list.name: What is a unordered/unsorted mutable list called?
name_of_unordered_mutable_list.comment: Set must be imported from the standard lib. It will be available without importing in the near future.

unordered_mutable_list_start_number.name: What number does it start at?

unordered_mutable_list_can_be_inserted_i.name: Can you insert into the middle of it?

insert_into_end_of_unordered_mutable_lis.name: Insert element at end
insert_into_end_of_unordered_mutable_lis.comment: sets are "unordered", but they always append to the end.

erase_element_in_middle_of_unordered_mut.name: Erase element in the middle
erase_element_in_middle_of_unordered_mut.comment: Learn more about deleting from sets in the Ruby docs: https://docs.ruby-lang.org/en/master/Set.html#class-Set-label-Methods+for+Deleting

delete_unordered_mutable_list.name: Delete the list
delete_unordered_mutable_list.comment: Empties the set, and returns an empty set.

name_of_ordered_immutable_list.name: What is a ordered (not sorted) immutable list called?
name_of_ordered_immutable_list.comment: To make something immutable in Ruby, you freeze it. Ordered immutable lists are arrays that have been frozen.

create_a_ordered_immutable_list.name: Create the list
create_a_ordered_immutable_list.comment: Constants (immutable values) are typically capitalized in Ruby.

ordered_immutable_list_start_number.name: What number does it start at?

delete_ordered_immutable_list.name: Delete the list
delete_ordered_immutable_list.comment: Immutable arrays raise an error if `clear` is called on them.

name_of_sorted_immutable_list.name: What is a sorted immutable list called?
name_of_sorted_immutable_list.comment: Ruby doesn't have a concept for a sorted that stays sorted when items are added or removed. Frozen arrays are immutable, so if the array is sorted before it's frozen, then it will technically maintain its order.

create_a_sorted_immutable_list.name: Create the list
create_a_sorted_immutable_list.comment: Arrays can be sorted before they are frozen.

sorted_immutable_list_start_number.name: What number does it start at?

delete_sorted_immutable_list.name: Delete the list
delete_sorted_immutable_list.comment: Immutable arrays raise an error if `clear` is called on them.

name_of_unordered_immutable_list.name: What is a unordered/unsorted immutable list called?

unordered_immutable_list_start_number.name: What number does it start at?

name_of_mutable_hashed_list.name: What is a mutable hashed list called?

create_a_mutable_hashed_list.name: Create the list
create_a_mutable_hashed_list.comment: Hash keys can be symbols, strings, or any other object. Symbols use the format `key:`. `melon:`, `'lemon':`, and `'root beer':` are symbols in this example. All other key types use hash rockets. For example, 1 and 'orange' which are integer and string keys.

erase_element_from_mutable_hashed_list.name: Erase an element from the list

name_of_immutable_hashed_list.name: What is an immutable hashed list called?
name_of_immutable_hashed_list.comment: To make something immutable in Ruby, you freeze it. Immutable hashed lists are hashes that have been frozen.

create_a_immutable_hashed_list.name: Create the list
create_a_immutable_hashed_list.comment: Constants (immutable values) are typically capitalized in Ruby.

erase_element_from_immutable_hashed_list.name: Erase an element from the list

get_key_from_mutable_set.name: Get key
get_key_from_mutable_set.comment: Grabs the first key from the list of keys for the hash.

get_all_values_from_mutable_set.name: Get all values
get_all_values_from_mutable_set.comment: Returns an array of values with no keys.

swap_key_and_value_in_mutable_set.name: Swap a key and value
swap_key_and_value_in_mutable_set.comment: If there are multiple keys with the same value, the last key added is the value.

delete_mutable_set.name: Delete the set
delete_mutable_set.comment: Sets the hash to an empty hash.

create_a_immutable_set.name: Create an immutable key/value set
create_a_immutable_set.comment: To make something immutable in Ruby, you freeze it. Immutable sets are hashes that have been frozen.

find_element_by_value.name: Find/search for an element by value
find_element_by_value.comment: First two lines are our array and hash. Third returns the index of orange, 1 in this case. Fourth line gives the key for 5, which is melon. The last line returns true, because a tomato is a fruit.

find_minimum_element.name: Find the minimum value in a list

find_maximum_element.name: Find the maximum value in a list

convert_list_to_string.name: Convert a list to a string

split_list_at_value.name: Split list at a value
split_list_at_value.comment: The second line returns an array containing 2 arrays. The array before 'tomato' and the array of 'tomato' and the rest.

duplicate_subset_of_list.name: Duplicate a portion/subset of a list

do_two_lists_match_exactly.name: Do two lists match every element?

do_two_lists_contain_same_items.name: Do two lists contain all the same items?

does_list_satisfy_some_expression.name: Does a list satisfy some expression?

does_list_not_satisfy_an_expression.name: Does a list entirely not satisfy an expression?

filter.name: Filter a list based on criteria
